headline: Gorka: I never said Tillerson was 'nonsensical' on NKorea
subHeadline: On 'Your World,' the White House adviser says his comment was about reporters 'forcing' the secretary of state into making statements on military options

utterances.speaker: SEBASTIAN GORKA, DEPUTY ASSISTANT TO PRESIDENT TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Childish, irresponsible. We have a grave threat to the region in the Korean Peninsula. We have a grave threat to the United States and her citizens. And this is what a so- called reputable newspaper wants to waste our time on? It's not even worth spending your time on or your viewers' time.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm going to take the time, because a lot of headlines have different interpretations of what the president said. But, in the past, during the campaign, he said things like: "I love war. I want to be unpredictable."  And he's also said, I guess, you know, what kind of things would really, really look like saber-rattling in advance, that he would be ready for that.   So, do you see how people could look at this statement and wonder what is next?

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: Only if they're irresponsible or if they have a political agenda to drive, instead of the truth. Look at the recent video that was released from 18 years ago with Tim Russert. This is a president who has understood for decades the geopolitics of the world, and especially the nuclear blackmail that North Korea has been trying to execute about the West.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: I know -- I know, Sebastian, that interview is stunning. But he also said in the same older interview that he feels he would negotiate crazily. He would negotiate like crazy. Do you feel that he and his team have reached that point, and it's saturated, and it's time to respond militarily?

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: What do you think after 30 years of appeasement?   This started -- the real American policy of appeasement started under the Clinton White House, Bill Clinton, and then exacerbated under the Obama White House. What has it led to?

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: And President Bush, too.

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: It's led to increased ballistic missile testing. It's led to increased nuclear weapons testing. How is following the course we followed for the last 20-plus years going to bring a resolution that is good for America or for the Korean Peninsula? It's failed. Just like appeasing Hitler in 1938 in Munich, appeasing the dictatorship in North Korea brings more escalation.  Think of the fact that, on, Saturday what happened? It wasn't some nations of the United Nations Security Council. All of them, to include China and Russia, said, enough is enough. That's all you need to know. The president has sent a signal.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: And, of course, you know, my dad was a doctor. He used to say, if you're using the same medication, and the patient isn't getting any better, change the medication. So, that may be exactly where he's going. I would be remiss if we didn't bring up what just happened at the secretary of state's spokesperson's meeting before the press this morning.  Now, let me back up here for our viewers who might not know. I believe, this morning, you gave an interview to BBC Radio, during which you said that it was nonsensical for Secretary of State Rex Tillerson to discuss military matters and that he was out of line.   Let's hear what she...

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: Never said that.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: You have never said...

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: I never said the secretary of state was -- that's fake news 101.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, there's audio of you saying the word nonsensical.

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: I have the audio. I have -- I have the audio as well. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: So, you're denying that you said that it's inappropriate perhaps for Rex Tillerson to have told the American people to calm down?

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Absolutely.  No, I never said that. I said for reporters to force our chief diplomat, the amazing Rex Tillerson, to give details of military options is nonsensical. He is the secretary of state. That means you don't understand what the words secretaries of state means. It's fake news, classic example.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, diplomacy does sometimes work hand in hand with military actions.

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. That's -- absolutely. But there's a secretary of defense, and there's a secretary of state.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: But, listen, it's now big enough -- it's now big enough that Heather Nauert, the spokesperson for Rex Tillerson, was asked about it.  She even said as she walking out to the press event there that she was told about it. So, let's hear what she had to say to reporters who asked.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.sentences: The suggestion that was made is that, basically, the secretary, Secretary Tillerson, shouldn't be involved or shouldn't be listened to as it relates to policy towards North Korea. Is that -- is that something that you agree with?

utterances.speaker: HEATHER NAUERT, STATE DEPARTMENT SPOKESWOMAN
utterances.sentences: I think I that everyone has clearly heard what Secretary Tillerson's forceful, forceful comments have been and continue to be on the issue of DPRK and other countries as well.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.sentences: And they should be paid attention to, right?

utterances.speaker: NAUERT
utterances.sentences: I would think so, yes.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.sentences: All right, so the idea that...

utterances.speaker: NAUERT
utterances.sentences: He's a Cabinet secretary. He's the fourth in line to the presidency. He carries a big stick.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.sentences: And Dr. Gorka is where in that line of succession?

utterances.speaker: NAUERT
utterances.sentences: I don't work with Dr. -- with Sebastian Gorka. I have known him from a previous life and a previous career, but I have not spoken to him about the comments that he made.

utterances.speaker: QUESTION
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: NAUERT
utterances.sentences: And let me just leave it at that.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: Sebastian, you know this is going to be all over the papers. And whether you had the exact meaning that people have now interpreted it as, it looks like, to some people, it looks like -- forget backstabbing -- that you front-stabbed the secretary of state.  And, you know, people look at that and say, who -- who was he to admonish any process that secretary of state would state? He's hand-picked by the president.

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: I was admonishing the journalists of the fake news industrial complex who are forcing our chief diplomat into a position where they're demanding he makes the military case for action, when that is not the mandate of the secretary of state.  That's why we have a Department of Defense. If a journalist doesn't know the difference between the secretary of state and the Department of Defense, they should hand in their credentials. It's just absurd lack of understanding. He is our most senior diplomat, and he's done an amazing job to get 15 nations of the U.N. Security Council to tell North Korea enough is enough. But when reporters try to force him to make statements regarding military options, they have no idea what they're talking about. And if they think that's a story, they're not journalists.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, he doesn't look like he was forced. I'm glad you're clearing up how you perceive it. But he didn't look like he was being forced to simply say we're not on the brink of war, certainly, with North Korea, and people should sleep at night.  And then, today, President Trump just said people of this country should relax.  What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: They should. Well, they absolutely should, because we have an administration, including Rex Tillerson, Secretary Mattis, the president, H.R. McMaster, individuals who are serious about the security of this nation, and they will take every measure, including diplomatic, including military, including financial, informational, intelligence, to secure this nation.  So, yes, everybody should rest easy that this administration will protect you. But if a journalist doesn't understand the difference between diplomacy and military affairs, then they're not fit to be journalists.

utterances.speaker: CLAMAN
utterances.sentences: Sebastian Gorka, thank you very much. We appreciate your coming on.

utterances.speaker: GORKA
utterances.sentences: Thank you.  END  Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2017 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
